titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1 V:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Bigelow, from John 4:9, “Then saith the woman of Samaria unto him, How is it that thou, being a Jew, askest drink of me; which am a woman of Samaria? for the Jews have no dealings with the Samaritans. 10. Jesus answered, and said unto her, if thou knewest the Gift of God, and who it is that saith to thee, Give me to drink: thou wouldest have asked of him, and he would have given thee living water”— After the service I called up Mr Southard, Mr Rush, and Mr Clay, who are all convalescent— Mr Southard had just received the account of the loss of his Election. Mr Frelinghuysen was first chosen to replace Mahlon Dickerson, whose term expires with this Session; and then after twelve ballottings Dickerson was chosen, for the remainder of Mr Bateman’s term— At the first Ballot, Mr Southard came within three votes of being elected— But a Resolution was offered and passed by a single vote, that he not being an inhabitant of the State, his name should be withdrawn— And then some of his friends joined with those who had voted for Dickerson—and brought him in against a Mr Ewing, who has divided the votes of Southard’s party, in the hope of coming in himself. So that Dickerson is now Senator from New-Jersey, both for himself and in the place of Bateman— While I was with Mr Southard, Mr Sergeant, and Mr Chambers came in— I found Mr Rush sitting up—his fever has left him, but he is yet very feeble. Mr Clay was much recovered— At St. John’s Church the whole afternoon service for the fourth Sunday after the Epiphany was performed; by a young Mr James of Georgetown, who preached a Sermon, from Job 31.14. “What then shall I do when God riseth up? and when he visiteth, what shall I answer him?” My attention flagged, at both the morning’s and the afternoon’s discourse. Mr Chambers, Senator from Maryland, Mr Silsbee, and Mr J. Sergeant dined with us— Mrs Smith is confined to her chamber— I suffer myself with a returning Cold— Mr Crowninshield’s Son Benjamin died last Monday, being that day 21 years of age. His father reached home a few hours after he had expired—
2. VI. Monday— Walk round Capitol Square.

Mr Graham the Commissioner of the General Land Office came and spoke of the locations of certain tracts of Land reserved to individual Pottawatima Indians by Treaty, upon ranges of Townships granted by an Act of Congress to the State of Indiana to aid in the making of a Canal— These locations were made by the Indian Agent Tipton, in consequence of a Letter from the Commissioner of the Land Office written last June, but which Mr Graham says Tipton misunderstood— They have been sold to white persons and are now nine of them in their possession— Tipton says they claim the right under the Treaty: and as antecedent to the grant to the State of Indiana— This is a subject which of course cannot be settled in my time— Mr Graham brought me also a Proclamation for a Sale of Lands in Monroe County, Michigan Territory, on the second Monday of June next, which I signed— Gregg was a man who came to beg or borrow money; a class of People, numerous in this Country who beset this house with infinite varieties of pretexts. Judge Thompson of the Supreme Court paid me a morning visit. He spoke of the issue of the recent Elections in New-York; in which he was the candidate opposed to Martin Van Buren— He says Van Buren told him that he would not have consented to be put in nomination for the Office of Governor, if any other man than Thompson had been nominated by the other party— Thompson had about 100,000 votes. Solomon Southick the anti-masonic candidate about 35000—and Van-Buren who succeeded 133000—not a majority of the whole. Mr Bates the member of the House of Representatives from Missouri called to enquire again for the papers which he left with me last Spring but which I have not yet been able to find— I sent to the Senate Message N. 19. with a Report from the Secretary of State concerning the recovery of debts due to American Citizens in Mexico—
3. VII:30. Wednesday.

Mr Lawrence, member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania introduced Mr Graham who solicited subscriptions for building a Church in Washington County of that State— William Lee spoke of a claim of Daniel Parker. heretofore Adjutant General, for double Rations, refused him by Mr Calhoun, who at the same time allowed them to other officers of the same rank, and under similar circumstances. Judge Johnson of the Supreme Court paid me a morning visit. His arrival here has been delayed about three weeks by the oversetting of the Stage in which he was coming—by which he received several severe contusions and dislocated the thumb of his right hand— But he says he can write nearly as well, with the pen between the knuckles of his fore and middle finger, as he did with his thumb and fore finger before the accident— Mr Tucker, member of the House of Representatives came to recommend his Son to nomination for appointment of Surveyor at the Port of Major Nourse brought me a bundle of Papers, copies in the case of General Scott— He told me General Porter had last Evening received a Note from General Scott tendering his resignation to take effect from the 3d. of March but asking a previous furlough for a year— Mr Wing introduced two of his friends from the Michigan Territory. Mr Elliot, with a young man named DeWitt brought back my Clock— Mr B. O. Tyler, Genl. Macomb and Mr Hassler were here successively; and Mr Dinsmoor, who left with me a Letter and an account of claims which he has to settle with the Treasury— We had company to dine. I. Bartlett, S. Bell, W. Cranch—J. and Mrs Dickinson—E and Mrs Everett, Nathl. and Mrs Frye, B. Gorham, Revd. W. and Mrs Hawley. Johnson, T. J. and Walter Hellen, Dr. H. Hunt, Judge Marshall, Miss Newman, J Sergeant, P. Sprague, Judge Story, Genl. Van Rensselaer, T. Watkins and Dr Worthington— Immediately before dinner, my Son’s daughter was baptised by the Revd. Mr Hawley, by the name of Mary Louisa— General Van Rensselaer and my wife stood the Sponsors— The evening was so cold, that I could not return to write in my chamber; and I lost near three hours this morning by late rising.
4: V:30. Wednesday.

Mr Fendall from the Department of State came to enquire whether the order which I had signed for the release of Obed Baxter from prison had been given by the general power of pardoning or by the Statute of I said it was by the Statute he being in execution upon a suit of debt upon the judgment, although the previous prosecution was upon a penal Statue. Mr Pearce member of the House of Representatives, and Mr Knight Senator from Rhode Island called successively called to enquire concerning the appointment of a Collector at Tiverton. Mr Johnston is the Indian Agent at Piqua Ohio. He came to urge my approbation of a second conveyance of the Van Meter Indian reservation of Lands, but my approbation of the prior sale must first be returned to me and cancelled— The widow Jones an elderly person came to see me for the mere sake of curiosity, and also for the first time in her life to ask assistance— Mr Southard had various papers both from the Treasury and Navy Departments—particularly the Report to the Commissioners of the sinking fund— Their Report to Congress, annual is to be made to-morrow— Mr Richardson a member of the House of Representatives from Massachusetts came to renew the solicitations for a pardon in favour of Amedey which I promised to take into serious consideration— Dr Watkins introduced a Mr Campbell, and Mr Woodcock, member of the House of Representatives from New-York, a Mr Catlett— Mr Janney came for my acceptance of a Bill of Exchange from J. H. March of Madeira for a half pipe arrived at New-York. I took up the Bill— Mr Nichol of the House of Smith and Nichol brought me a Letter from J. Sergeant— His object is to obtain a motion from the Attorney-General to the Supreme Court, to take up the Thompson Tea Case, in which Nichol is concerned, by preference and out of its order upon the Docket. I told him I would readily consent to it, if the health of the Attorney General was so far restored that he would be able to argue it— Cold Evening— Potowmac frozen over.
5. VI:15. Thursday.— Walk round Capitol Square

Mr Williams called and took his Letters of Recommendation— He is going to return to South-Carolina, and says he shall leave his Letters with judge Cranch— Mr White the Delegate from Florida, brought his manuscript compilation of the Spanish Colonial Land Laws, which he appeared to wish might be communicated by me to Congress. He left with me the preliminary Letter to the Secretary of State— Mr Iredell the Senator and Mr Maxwell, member of the House of Representatives, of the Committee of Enrolled Bills, brought me four Bills and a joint Resolution, to be signed. Mr Iredell said the Resolution related to the printing of Congress; and the House of Representatives had fixed on this day for the Election of a Printer. I signed and returned the Resolution and the Bills— General Porter brought me the Letter of Genl. Scott which Major Nourse had mentioned— It is not a tender of his Resignation; but a request for an informal permission to go to Richmond; and a declaration, that it is his determined intention, if Congress do not by the third of March pass an Act to relieve him from his present Situation, to tender his resignation of whatever rank he holds in the Army of the United States. William Tharp came to renew his complaints and invectives upon the accounting Officers of the Treasury; for refusing to pay him as Administrator upon the Estates of deceased Soldiers, the whole amount of the pay due to them— The regulation being that to Suttlers, Administrators the payments shall be made, only of the sums due to them—the remainder being retained, for the contingency of children or relatives appearing entitled to claim it—By the general Law an Administrator is doubtless entitled to the possession of all the effects of his deceased; but the regulation is intended to obviate frauds upon Relatives; and Tharp’s claim is peculiarly disgraced by his having presented accounts apparently sworn to before magistrates in 1813. with a watermark of 1816 upon the paper— I wrote this Evening some lines in Miss M’Knight’s Album— John dined with Mr Rebello, the Brazilian Chargé d’Affaires—
6. VII:15 Friday— Walk round Capitol Square

Dr. Wallace came, this morning, and we had a long conversation upon Matter and Spirit, Light and Heat, Snow and Rain; till it came to philosophical religion— His mind is perpetual motion— Thinking and reasoning upon every thing; but exercising the Fancy so much and the judgment so little, that he comes to no useful conclusion— Among his experiments he says he took some of the poison of the Rattlesnake inwardly to try its effects upon the human constitution; and that it gave him the dropsy.— We were interrupted by Coll. Washington who introduced to me five of his Constituents from Frederick— Mr Brent from the Department of State came for a despatch lately received from J. J. Appleton the Charge d’Affaires at Stockholm— Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought a Resolution of the Senate, calling for a detailed statement of expenses of the South Sea expeditions and a detailed statement of the amount of transfers of appropriation for this object, and the authority by which they have been made. Mr Clay was here; the first time since his illness. He said the Ratification of the Prussian Government had arrived, to the Treaty signed by him and Mr Niederstetter, but it had come five days after the time limited—for the Exchange of the Ratifications— There was a question whether it must again be submitted to the Senate for their advice and consent to the exchange— The Prussian Government propose some additional articles, which if they are of a nature to be agreed upon immediately, I thought might be concluded, and sent to the Senate all together. Mr Clay wishes that a call may be made for the Instructions to the Ministers of the Panama Mission to which I assented. Mr Johnston, Senator from Louisiana came to make some enquiries concerning the time of Judge Trimble’s death— The Senate are debating upon question whether they will act upon the nomination of his successor—or any other of my nominations during the present Session— They will postpone all or most of them— Mr Kerr came to solicit a Midshipmans Warrant for a Son of Dr Thomas of Frederick.
7. VI:15 Saturday— Sun rose 7.6: and capped the dome of the Capitol—

We commenced this day the removal of our furniture to Commodore Porter’s House on Meridian Hill. This I have taken as a temporary shelter until the mildness of the Season may admit of my wife’s journeying northward to Quincy. Mr Johnston the Indian Agent came to urge my approval of an Indian deed of Land— But I had signed an offer by another man of a larger sum for the same land, and told Mr Johnson I could not approve this, unless my former signature of approbation should be returned to me, and cancelled— He took back the Deed and papers— Mr Clay mentioned the interview he has had with Mr Niederstetter the Prussian Charge d’Affaires— His Government propose three additional Articles to the Treaty— To abolish privateering. To define Blockades, and to amend the description of military Stores in the List of Contraband of the concluded Treaty— We thought it most advisable, to defer the Negotiation; till the next President shall enter upon his Office. Judge Hay and Mr Edwards formerly a Senator from Connecticut paid morning visits— Major Nourse Chief Clerk of the War Department, brought a list of nominations of the Militia Officers for the territory of Michigan— Mr Robbins Senator from Rhode-Island introduced Mr Hazard and Mr Browne— Mr M’lean the Post-master General came for the papers he had sent me remonstrating against the appointment of N Low, as Postmaster at Portland, and said he would sent him his commission. Mr Southard advised with me on various business both of the Navy and Treasury Departments But said Mr Rush was so far recovered that he proposed returning the duties of the Office on Monday— Mr Southard promised to send me then a Report upon the Resolution of the Senate concerning the expenses of the South Sea Expedition— Mr White the Delegate from Florida, called about the papers of his compilation, and an account of 1500 dollars to be paid him— Mr Bryan of North-Carolina, member of the house introduced Mr Sheppard a young man from that State— Mr Bailey spent the Evening with me—
8. V. Sunday— Rain

Heard Mr Bigelow—from John 4.20. “Our fathers worshipped in this mountain, and ye say, that in Jerusalem is the place where men ought to worship”— The discourse was upon religious discord, and gave a striking picture of the rancorous spirit of hostility which existed between the Jews and the Samaritans. He did not however consider it historically, but merely as a religious feud upon the question where should be the place of worship— And he said that the dissensions among Christians now, were quite as frivolous, being not indeed on the where, but on the how, the Creator should be worshipped. This subject would furnish a text for an impressive political discourse— The religious dissensions between the Jews and the Samaritans were consequent upon their political division— It was Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who after the revolt of the ten tribes from the House of David, set up the golden Calves in Bethel and in Dan, and made priests of the lowest of the people, and established a heretical, semi-idolatrous worship in Samaria, to prevent the ten tribes from returning to their subjection to the descendants of David. It was one of the consequences of the division of the kingdom—the Temple of Solomon, and the Ark of the Covenant remaining at Jerusalem— The immediate cause of the revolt was heavy taxation occasioned by the disorders and extravagance of the Old Age of Solomon— The wars that followed the division were sectional, and sectarian; and finally terminated in the conquest and captivity of both parties— The kingdom of Israel by Shalmaneser king of Assyria, and afterwards that of Judah by Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. The details of the History from the division to the conquest would yield a fund of valuable matter for a political Dissertation, and illustrate the value and importance of Union— I will take it up if I have leisure hereafter— The storm of rain continued through the whole of this day— There was no afternoon service at St. John’s Church.— I occupied the leisure of the day in preparing a Message to the Senate with army Nominations, and in signing Land-grants of which 11 were sent me from the Land Office yesterday— I received also a Note with a list of nominations from the Secretary of the Navy—
9. VI. Monday.— Walk round Capitol Square.

Mr Dorsey, member of the House of Representatives from Maryland introduced three of his Constituents from Frederick. He is very unwell with the Sciatica, of which he had a severe spasm here on rising from his chair. Mr Hendricks, Senator from Indiana introduced the Revd. Mr M’Coy, who left with me a deed to him in trust of a Section of Land reserved to an Indian, and granted by him to the missionary Establishment— Mr Clay spoke of the case of the Buenos-Ayrean Privateer federal, the Captain of which presented himself here yesterday as a Prisoner, as he had engaged to do— But we agreed that we had no solid ground, upon which a prosecution could be maintained against him; and that he should be informed that he might go where he pleased. Mr Rush was here, having this day resumed the performance of his duties at the Treasury Department. He informed me that Mr Southard was grievously ill again, seized last Night with cramps in the Stomach; and confined to his bed this day, unable to see any body— I sent for Charles Hay, Chief Clerk of the Navy Department, and requested him to collect as soon as possible the Statements for the answer to the Resolution of the Senate concerning the South-Sea Scientific expedition. Mr Frye came to recommend James Wells for a Cadet’s warrant at West-Point— Mr White, the Delegate from Florida, about his compilation of Spanish Colonial Laws— Mr Wilde, member of the House from Georgia, for two Letters he had sent me from C. J. Meigs and H. Meigs, which I returned to him with a Midshipman’s Warrant for J. B. Meigs— Mr Dupont of Delaware said he had come here, and settled with the Ordnance Department, an old affair, of a loan of gun powder from the Government to his establishment which has been returned to the great advantage of the Government. Mr Whittlesey called for the decision in the case of Robert Eaton. The papers are to be returned to the Treasury— General Porter was here with his wife’s brother, the Revd. W. Breckenridge— The General wishes for a decision upon his claim— Mr Everett and J. W. Taylor spent part of the Evening with me.
10. V:45. Tuesday— Walk round Capitol Square— Snow.

Mr Knight a Senator, and Mr Burges and Mr Pearce, members of the House of Representatives from Rhode-Island, came together, to request a further application of funds for a marine hospital at Providence— 5000 dollars had been appropriated nearly two years since to that object at the solicitation of Mr Burges; on condition that the Town of Providence should give the ground upon which the building was to be erected— But the ground which they gave was not suitable for the edifice— The Collector thought it too far distant; and now they wish to provide another place; but need about 3000 dollars more of the public funds.— I advised that a written application should be made to the Secretary of the Treasury, upon which I would examine the subject, and decide on it— Mr Chambers, Senator from Maryland came with Mr Munro the Editor of the Baltimore Patriot. General Porter was here and spoke of his claim; the particulars of which I examined.— I found that C. P. Van Ness had retained of public monies in his hands a Salary of 4444 dollars a year, in the face of an Act of Congress reducing it to 2500. Van Ness says he will have a judicial decision upon it. John Ross and others, a Delegation of Cherokee Indians wrote a Note requesting to see me, which I gave to the Secretary of War and agreed to receive these at noon to-morrow— Mr Lee the third Auditor came in great distress— Upon the Election of a Printer for the next Congress, in the House of Representatives this day— There were 208 members present 107. for Duff Green—95 for Gales and Seaton 6 scattering, so that Green was elected—and the Retrenchment Committee have reported a Bill to abolish the Offices of the second Auditor (Lee) and the 2d. Comptroller R. Cutts— Mr Brent called from the Department of State— Dr Harris was here in the Evening and mentioned that he had called at the request of Mr Southard, to say that he was too ill to be able to attend to business, and probably would continue so for some days— I wrote this Evening a Message to both Houses to send with Coll. White’s Letter to the Secretary of State on the Florida Land Ordinances.
11. VI. Wednesday.

Mr Pearce, a member of the House of Representatives from Rhode Island called to say that he had received a Letter from Job Durfee, so exceedingly urgent for the appointment of his brother Charles Durfee as Surveyor of Tiverton, that although he had recommended another Man, he should be as well satisfied, if Durfee should be appointed— Job was Mr Pearce’s predecessor in Congress and his competitor when Pearce was elected— He considers this as an appeal to his magnanimity. Mr Southard’s nephew called with the draught of his Report upon the Resolution of the Senate, which he had prepared before his sudden illness, and which he wishes may be soon sent in— Mr Lowrie Secretary of the Senate brought me another Resolution of that body; calling for the Letters to the Secretary of State of Mr Holmes, while he was Commissioner under the 4th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent— Mr Dwight member of the House from Massachusetts, and Mr Whittlesey, member from Ohio came on a morning visit— Mr Whittlesey spoke of a claim of payment for a Company of Volunteers during the late War, which I had not yet examined. I sent for Mr Pleasonton, to enquire concerning the account of C. P. Van Ness, as Commissioner under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent— There is a balance against him, for which I directed that a suit should be commenced. I made also some enquiries respecting the claim of Genl. Hull’s Executor, for answer to which application is to be made to the first Auditor— Mr Gales, the Mayor, brought a Resolution of the Corporation of the City, asking a grant of part of the Presidents Square, for a Basin at the termination of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal— I thought I had no power to grant the Land— Mr Gales took the Lottery Resolution which had left with me some months since which I had approved— This day the votes for the Election of President and Vice-President of the United States for four years from the 4th. of March next were opened and Andrew Jackson of Tennessee, declared President, and John C. Calhoun Vice-President— The President elect came into the City; and I received a Letter from my Son Charles, with the pamphlet published by the Boston Confederates against me.
12. VI. Thursday. Walk round the Square

Mr Southard’s nephew brought me a note from him, and took his draft of a Report upon the Resolution of the Senate relating to the expenses of the South-Sea expedition. Mr Fendall and Mr Lee called together; Mr Jennings had a memorial from Alexandria soliciting the discharge from prison of a boy confined for the costs on a prosecution for Assault and Battery. I told Mr Jennings that an endorsement of recommendation by the District Attorney or one of the Judges would be necessary— Mr White the Delegate from Florida came to enquire again about his Report on the Spanish Colonial Land Ordinances— I sent copies of it in to both Houses of Congress with Message N. Mr Clay was here and spoke of his reply to the Spanish Minister Tacon, concerning Mr Salmon’s quarrel with the Kurke family. Mr Rush had a Letter from Mr Goodsell, the Agent who has been employed upon the Canada frontier to enquire of smuggling. But we were interrupted— General Porter came with the four Cherokee Chiefs, one only of whom had any perceptible remnant of Indian colour— They had addressed a memorial to the Secretary of War, containing several complaints with regard to the non-payment of annuities, and other objects, which I now read, and upon which I desired that a report should be made by Coll. M’Kenney—and I promised to see as far as may be in my power that Justice shall be done them— Coll. Jones the Adjutant General introduced Major Davenport and Dr Thomas of the Army— Captain of the Navy who has been on a two years furlough and just returned— Mr Gunnell and Mr Mullen came to solicit a contribution for finishing and repairing a Baptist Church at the Navy-Yard. Judge Hay called but finding other company here said he would come again— Shanneburgh is a young man, who has been some months soliciting an appointment of Lieutenant in the Marine Corps. Hearing that I had nominated another person, he seemed to consider that I had thereby violated his right— Dr Watkins called to shew me a miniature portrait of Genl. Bolivar; belonging to Coll. Wilson, his Aid de Comp, son of Sir Robert Wilson, and who is now here. We had this Evening an Oyster Supper.
13. VI:30 Friday. Snow— Walk round the Square—

Dr Wallace came, and had a long conversation with me upon natural history— I asked him if he had ever directed his researches to an enquiry into the causes of the comparative longevity of man, and of other animals— He said he had not— I enquired if there was any medical writer who had investigated or discussed the subject. He said there was not, to his knowledge— He spoke of the Polytheism of Christianity— I told him there was no Polytheism in any sect of Christianity, and in proof of it read to him the Athanasian creed, of which he had never heard— He says he cannot pray, because he thinks it impious—and he never goes to Church. Mr Southard was here twice. The first time with his Uncle’s Report on the Resolution of the Senate concerning the South-Sea expedition; with its accompanying documents, and the second to ask for them again— He at first wished them to be sent in this day; and afterwards to delay the Message till Monday— Mr Scull came to solicit a contribution for building a Methodist Church in some part of Maryland— Mr and Mrs Cleaveland of Lancaster Massachusetts paid me a visit; being on their return homeward from a visit to Norfolk, Virginia— Mr Rush had several Accounts of individuals to be allowed for services as Counsel to the United States in Judicial Courts, and one a Mr Dean for investigating charges against the Register and Receiver of the Land-Office at Cahawba— He read me also Mr Goodsell’s Letter which asserts that there is a very extensive system of smuggling projected on the Northern frontier— He wishes to have a personal conference with the Secretary of the Treasury to make verbal communications—but we thought this could lead to no measure of the Government— Mr Richard Maury called to take leave of me, and thank me for kindness to his late father— In the Evening Genl. Van Rensselaer and Mr Everett came in behalf of Mr Nicoll to urge the calling up the case in which he is concerned out of turn before the Supreme Court; out of turn— I declared my own willingness and wish for it but mentioned the objections of the Attorney General against. I promised however to see him and propose it to him again.
14. VI. Saturday— Walk round Capitol Square—

Mr Wirt the Attorney General called— I told him of the promise I had made to advise him to move the Supreme Court to take up the Thomson tea case, by preference before its turn— He said that the other cases equally important must be postponed if that should be taken up— That the Record was so voluminous it would take him an entire fortnight to make himself master of it, so as properly to argue the cause— And that it would be necessary for him to withdraw from the Court during the whole of that time— After much conversation in which I stated my own anxiety to have the Nicoll case brought as soon as possible to a final decision he agreed to state the facts to the Court, and take their decision whether a preference should be given to that case or not. Mr Silsbee introduced his relative Jacob Crowninshield and a young Mr Endicott— Dr Todsen, and Major Hamilton, came to renew solicitations for appointments which I have not to bestow. Mr Brent came with a request from Baron Krudener for an Audience to deliver a Letter from the Emperor Nicholas, announcing the death of the Empress Mother. I fixed Monday at One O’ Clock— Mr Holmes, Senator from Maine, spoke of a call by his Colleague Chandler, for his Holmes’s correspondence with the Secretary of State in 1816 and 17 when he was Commissioner under the 4th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent— He knows not what Chandler’s object is— Mr Chase a Senator from Vermont introduced Lieutenant Rissell, and Mr Storrs, member from New-York came with Mr Talcott of that State— Mr Derrick, brought a Letter from Mr Niederstetter the Prussian Chargé d’Affaires, proposing the negotiation of Additional Articles to the Treaty and asking explanation of one of the Articles concluded—with the draft of Mr Clay’s answer which I approved— I had morning visits from Mr Merwin, a member of the House of Representatives from Connecticut, from Mr D. B. Ogden of New-York, and from Coll. Bomford with Mr Baldwin of Pittsburg, whose presence here may indicate that he is to be a member of the next Administration.
15. VI: Sunday.

Heard Mr Bigelow from Acts 5.38—“If this counsel or this work be of men, it will come to nought— 39. But if it be of God; ye cannot overthrow it; lest haply ye be found even to fight against God.” A historical discourse commenting upon the opposition which the Christian religion has had to encounter and overcome; from the crucifixion of Jesus, and the first persecution of Nero, to the tenth under Diocletian— He gave some details of the first, the sixth and the tenth—and an eloquent extemporaneous amplification of the ignominious character of death upon the accursed tree— In the afternoon at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley read the abridged evening service for Septuagesima Sunday, and preached from Revelation 22.17— “And the Spirit and the bride say come. And let him that heareth say, come. And let him that is athirst come. And whosoever will, let him take the water of life freely.” I think I had heard the Sermon before— In the interval between the Services I had visits from Mr Sergeant; from Judge Hay with the Marshal Ringgold, and from Mr Kerr, member of the House of Representatives from Maryland, with one of his Constituents, Dr Thomas, who came to thank me for a Midshipman’s warrant obtained for his son, at the Solicitation of Mr Kerr— Mr Ringgold told me he would call again to shew me a Letter from General La Fayatte to Mr Monroe— Mr Silsbee, with his young friends Jacob Crowninshield and Endicott, J. Sergeant, and Mr Gales, the Mayor of the City, dined with us— I spoke to Mr Gales of certain additional papers which I propose to publish with the pamphlet of the Boston Confederates. Gales said he had intended to postpone the republication of the pamphlet in the Intelligencer—but would call on me again in a day or two— He told me that the papers signed Massachusetts in the National Intelligencer of January and February 1820. were written by John Bailey— Sergeant shewed us a strange anonymous confidential Note in the hand-writing of A. Smyth, of which and several others of the same kind, notice has been taken in the House of Representatives, where they have excited some merriment.
16. VI:15. Monday Walk round the Square

Mr Leffler member of the House of Representatives from Virginia, called and introduced to me one of his Constituents— Leffler says that he is tired of coming to Congress, and intends to decline a re-election— General Porter called and took the papers relating to his claim, upon which I told him I thought the Executive was precluded from acting. Mr Monroe having signed the Acts of Congress, limiting the Salary and he and I having both signed the annual Appropriation Bills, after the expiration of the limiting act, but upon estimates of the continuance of the limited Salaries— It was a judicial question, and I had directed Pleasonton to commence a suit against C. P. Van Ness for the balance that he had retained in his hands. General Porter brought me also an insulting and insolent Letter from General Gaines to which I requested him to prepare a reply— Mr Rush mentioned that he had yesterday paid a visit with Mrs. Rush to the President elect— Mr Clay introduced to me in private Audience, Baron Krudener the Russian Minister, who delivered to me a Letter from the Emperor Nicholas, announcing the death of the Empress Mother, on the 24th. October 1828 O.S—or the 5th. of November. I assured the Baron of the interest with which the United States would sympathize in, this afflictive dispensation of Providence to the Emperor and his family—and of the peculiar concern which I personally felt from the opportunity I had enjoyed of witnessing her great and good qualities, and of experiencing her kindness— The Baron was reciprocally obliging, and in terms of delicacy intimated his regret that the administration was so near its close— Mr Southard was here, looking like one rising from the grave. He said he was never so near death as last Monday morning— Coll. Ogden of New-Jersey introduced to me, Mr Thomas and Mr Holsted of that State— Coll. White of Florida called to recommend the dismission from Office of a person of the same name in that Territory, without hearing his defence— But this I could not do. Captain Partridge introduced Dr Colton of Middletown Connecticut.
17. VI:15 Tuesday— Walk round the Square

Mr Brent brought me three pamphlets published by W. B. Giles— I asked him to send me certain Volumes of Newspapers at the Department— My special object was to find an Article in the New-York American of 19. January 1820— Headed Hartford Convention— Mr Mallary member of the House of Representatives from Vermont, introduced judge Hubbard, Mr Bronson, and his Son, from that State— Mr Bigelow came with DrBigelBarlar? of Hingham who told me that he had left Mr Quincy and his Son in Law Mr Green at Philadelphia two days since— Mr Quincy has been recently elected President of Harvard University— Mr Gurley, member of the House of Representatives from Louisiana, came with Mr John Nicholson of New-Orleans, who spoke of a recommendation of a Mr Maybin for the Office of U.S. District Attorney there in the place of Mr Smith appointed a State Judge— Mr Scott came to make his last Solicitation to me for an Office— He has been an applicant many years; and thinks it mysterious that he has not yet obtained any Appointment. He is very sincere in his want of it—and in his acknowledgments that he cannot live and educate his children well without it. Finding there was no prospect of a vacancy during the few remaining days of this Administration, he asked me to return to him the Letters of Recommendation which he had heretofore produced, and for which I promised to have search made— General Van Rensselaer, his Son, and Mr and Mrs Everett, spent part of the Evening here, and supped with us— I am much occupied, and in the accumulated business at the close both of a Session of Congress, and of an Administration, I am interrupted by a formidable and violent controversy— I have commenced the preparation of my reply to the Appeal of the Boston Confederates— I wrote this day to my brother and to Thomas Jefferson Randolph, and sent to Jonathan Elliot sundry papers to be added to the republication of the Boston Pamphlet among them my Letter to Mr Plumer of 16. Augt 1809. and his letter to me of 20. December last.
18. V:30. Wednesday.— Walk round the Square

Mr Fendall, of the Department of State, brought me a manuscript political Index, kept by himself, referring to the dates of controversial publications in the principal newspapers of the last three years; which he thought might be useful to me to consult. I had a long conversation with Mr Fendall upon the pamphlet of the Boston confederates, and told him many circumstances of the times to which this controversy goes back— Mr Rush came in, and broke off this conversation with business from the Treasury— I remitted a penalty and forfeiture on the petition of Lorenzo R. Wallace; and referred to my Successor a claim of Alexander Anderson— I sent back to the Treasury many papers upon which I deemed it unnecessary to make any decision, and wish to postpone every thing upon which immediate decision is not necessary. Mr Cooper came and earnestly solicited the nomination of himself as a Purser; and told me that young Mr Donelson General Jackson’s nephew, who had been a Classmate of his at West-Point, had promised him that if I should nomination, and the Senate should not confirm the nomination, the General would renominate him after the fourth of March— General Porter brought several Accounts of William Clark and John Johnston for claims of compensation for Indian Agencies— I shall pass them all over to my Successor. He introduced to me his nephew: Commodore Patterson, and Dr Huntt came to invite my attendance next Monday at the Washington birth-night Ball— I thanked them for the invitation, and told them that my attendance would depend upon circumstances— Mr Southard was here with a large file of papers, from Captain Turner of the Erie, concerning his capture of the Buenos-Ayrean Schooner. Federal— Also a Letter of Instruction to Commodore Ridgely commanding the Station at Pensacola, directing the judicial trial of the case— Mr Sergeant and Mr Quincy the President Elect of Harvard University were here successively this Evening— Sergeant enquired whether General Jackson had called upon me. I had some conversation with Mr Quincy upon the Boston Pamphlet. He spoke of Hamilton’s posthumous paper—
19. VI:15. Thursday— Walk round the Square

Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate, brought me three Resolutions of that Body; one referring to the President of the United States a petition of John Baker of Maine, one advising and consenting to two Indian Treaties which had been sent to them last Winter; and one confirming the single nomination of Nathan Smith as District Attorney in Connecticut— They kept the original Indian Treaties, and sent me only a printed Copy of them by a new Rule, which they have adopted at this Session. I said they should at least send back those Treaties which had been sent to them before they had adopted their rule.— Dr Wallace was here I believe three hours; outsitting every body, and declaiming against Slavery— Mr Floyd of Florida called with Mr Talbot of Virginia, and Mr Barker of New-York— Floyd was one of the Candidates for the appointment of Collector of the Port of Magnolia— He desired that the recommendation of him might be returned to him which was done— Mr Fendall brought me a copy of Matthew Carey’s Olive Branch— Also a pamphlet containing my Letter in answer to A. Smyth, and my Speech on the Louisiana Convention-Bill— Mr Seymour Senator from Vermont, came, and spoke of some of the proceedings in the Senate; but Dr Wallace would not budge— A young man named Bird of Boston Grandson of Joseph Woodward called—returning from the South to Boston. Coll. Thomas was here and had some small gossiping anecdotes— Dr Wallace said he had gone to pay a visit to General Jackson, and J. P. Van Ness of the Central Committee, who acts as Master of the Ceremonies introduced him as an Aristocrat—at which Wallace is indignant— Coll. Gratiot came to urge his claim for nomination as Brigadier General by Brevet; and cited a precedent in the case of Coll. Thayer— William Tharp brought me some papers again relating to his claim, and said Mr. Bates of Missouri would call upon me to-morrow. Mr Bryan of North-Carolina, introduced to me his brother— Mr Gales the Mayor brought with him a plan shewing the small piece of ground on the President’s Square which they want to make the Basin of their Canal— Mr Gales mentioned that the Senate had this day elected Duff Grean, printer to the next Congress 24 to 16— Mr T. Munroe the Postmaster paid me a morning visit.
20. VI:15— Friday— Snow. Walk round the Square—

There was again a heavy fall of Snow this morning, the third that we have had this winter, and about noon it held up and cleared off with a Northwest gale and the thermometer about 20. I spoke to Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate for a copy of the Executive Journal of that body, for the present Session of Congress; which he said he thought should be furnished me, but the copy of which must be made out, after I shall be out of office— A young man named Taylor from New-York who has been applying here for a purser’s commission came and said he would give up the pursuit and go home— I advised him rather to leave his name on the Register of Candidates at the Navy Department, and take his chance of obtaining the appointment hereafter, which he finally concluded to do— Mr White of Florida, came with Mr Slacum who is also a Candidate for a purser’s appointment. And failing in that he wished the appointment as Collector in place of a man who Mr White thinks should be removed, without a hearing— An example which I told him I could not think of setting at this Stage of the Administration— Mr Quincy and his Son in Law Mr Green paid me a visit; and promised to dine with me on Sunday. Mr Quincy did intend to visit the University at Charlottesville; though he says the paragraph in the newspapers announcing that this was the object of his journey was unauthorized. The University has broken up for the present on the appearance of an infectious distemper with which two or three of the Students have died— Gustavus H. Scott came to tell me that he was informed the Penitentiary Bill would certainly pass this Session; and that the appointment of the Warden would be given to the President alone. And he began a new dissertation upon his extreme want of the place— I told him that if the appointment should fall to me, I would duly consider his claim— I walked round the Capitol Square with difficulty, returning against the North-western Gale— Sent three Messages to the Senate N. 25. nominating Coll. Gratiot, Chief Engineer to be a Brigadier General by Brevet. N. 26. with a Report from the Secretary of State and J. Holmes’s Correspondence with that Department as Commissioner under the 4th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent; and N. 27. a Report from the Secretary of the Treasury with vouchers shewing the expenses of Land-Surveys and Sales in 1827.
21. VI:15 Saturday— Walk round the Square

The Seneca Indian Chief Red Jacket called upon me, with his interpreter Henry Johnson to take leave of me, and to ask some assistance for him to return home, for which I referred him to the Secretary of War— He has been exhibiting himself for sometime past upon Theatres in several of our Cities for Money— He carries with him a small silver mounted emblematic tomahawk— He told me that he came to take leave of me for that he and I were of the last Age and should soon be called for by the Great Spirit— I answered him that was true, and I hoped it would be to a better world than this. William Tharp came twice; and took back the papers he has last left with me— Mr Silsbee introduced to me a Mr Neal from Salem— Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate, brought me the two Indian Treaties, which they have consented to send back to be ratified, by an exception to their new Rule— Mr Fendall came and took the Treaties— I had a long conversation with him upon the subject of this contemplated History. Mr Rush was here only a moment to ask for a paper. General Porter spoke of the Accounts and claims of Governor Cass, General Clark and John Johnston for Indian agencies which I referred over to my Successor. He told me that he could not appoint Charles King’s Son a Cadet at West-Point, New-York having already an undue proportion— Mr David B. Ogden introduced Judge Haliburton and his Son, of Halifax Nova-Scotia. Coll. Jones the Adjutant General brought me two small volumes, one containing the army Regulations, and the other the decisions upon Court-Martials, during the present Administration, from 1825 to 1829. that is all the Regulations sanctioned by me, and all my decisions upon Army Court Martials. General Macomb called and we had a long Conversation upon the Affairs of the Army— In my walk I met Mr Bailey whom I asked if he was the author of the pieces signed Massachusetts in the National Intelligencer of January and February 1820. He told me that he was.
22. VI:15. Sunday.

Heard at the Unitarian Church, Mr Bigelow, from Jeremiah 6.8. “Be thou instructed, O Jerusalem, lest my soul depart from thee; lest I make thee desolate, a land not inhabited.” It was the first of a Series of Discourses upon the moral influence of Christianity upon the world. The text is not so opposite to the Doctrine as many others which might have been selected; but the Sermon itself was of a high order of composition— It was indeed upon the same Subject on which I had heard two or three Sermons of Mr Bigelow before— They are powerful in reasoning and Eloquence, but sometimes perhaps too Sectarian— He this day attributed the difference between the political character of our Revolution and History, and that of the new South-American States, to the Roman Catholic influence in that Country, and the Protestant predominance in ours. True, but perhaps not expedient to be told at this time and place— I asked Judge Story to call upon me at four O’Clock— He came and I asked him if I could consult him as a friend upon a subject of deep importance to me— He readily assented, and as an evidence of the interest which he had long since taken of in my character he mentioned that in the winter of 1816–1817. he had earnestly advised Mr Monroe to appoint me Secretary of State— I then related to him the present state of my controversy with the Boston Confederates, and my intention to publish in the course of the Summer a reply to their appeal— I said I wished to proceed in this matter with deliberation and advice— I had hitherto taken that of my friends here— Of this I should henceforth be deprived, and wished for that of a sober judicious and intelligent person, at every step I shall take. He said he would very cheerfully comply with my request— He said he had read the additional papers in Elliot’s republication of the pamphlet, and had been astonished at the strength of the Evidence they contained in support of my charges— He regretted the necessity of these publications, and mentioned his friendly regard for some of the confederates— Judge Story, and Messrs Bailey, Bartlett, Dwight, Green, Quincy and Sergeant dined with us—
23. VI. Monday.— Washington’s birth-night Ball—

Mr Ringgold the Marshal called this morning, and offered to attend me this Evening to the Ball— I desired him to come in the course of the week, and with Mr Elgar take an inventory of the furniture in the House, belonging to the Public, and to be delivered up: and to inform General Jackson that the House would be ready to receive him and his family by the 4th of next month— Mr Bell Senator from New-Hampshire called and had some conversation with me, but we were interrupted— Mr Clay said that Mr Niederstetter had spoken to him about the Exchange of the Ratifications of the Treaty with Prussia— I determined to leave it to my Successor— It was a question whether the Treaty should be resubmitted to the Senate for their advice and consent to the Exchange of the ratifications, because the Treaty arrived here with the Prussian ratification five days after the time limited for the exchange— I consider it a mere formality in Execution of the Treaty, and not requiring any Agency of the Senate— But as Mr Clay had some doubts, I preferred leaving the question to be decided by my Successor. Mr Mitchell, member of the House from S.C. introduced Mr Rees of Charleston. Mr Locke, member of the House from Massachusetts, came and took several Letters recommendatory of T. Bartlett, for the appointment of Collector at Plymouth. Coll. Abert paid me a morning visit— He has now the place at the topographical bureau, vacated by the death of Coll Roberdeau— I desired him to send for the Telescope and Chronometer that I have had in use here; but which belong to the war Department. Lloyd Rogers called and reminded me of a Journey upon which he and I were fellow-travellers, from Baltimore to New-York in March 1807—and of several incidents which occurred upon that Journey, among which that I then mentioned to Seth Hastings the disunion project of 1804 and then told him, that I had had information of it from Rufus King— He spoke also of their incidents—of Egbert Benson’s having heard from Rufus King through a Mr Bogert that I was mad for believing that the federalists intended a dissolution of the Union—and of a warning given by Oliver Wolcott to a company where Major Delafield was present against Hartford Convention politicians. I went this Evening to the Ball at Masonic Hall, with T. Ringgold, and Abigail.
24. VI. Tuesday.— Walk round the Square

I desired Mr Ringgold the Marshal yesterday to inform General Jackson that the House would be ready to receive him—on the fourth of March. He brought me for answer that the General cordially thanked me and hoped I would put myself to no inconvenience, to quit the house, but remain in it as long as I pleased; even for a Month. This morning Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought me the advice and consent of that body to the appointment of Joseph Hopkinson, as U.S. District Judge for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, and a Resolution calling for an Account of the expenses of the Land Office in 1827. I had in my walk yesterday met Mr Silsbee, who informed me that the Senate had confirmed Hopkinson’s appointment— Mr Tracy member of the House of Representatives from New-York brought a petition for a pardon to a mail carrier convicted of stealing from the Mail— I read to him my decision in the case of the boy Rose; and my Letter to Mr Taliaferro. I said if he would send me a Letter enclosing his Petition, I would answer him and give him a copy of the decision in Rose’s case, containing my reasons for declining to grant pardons for that offence— General Boyd, and Mr Dyer of Boston, visitors here in search of place paid me a morning visit— Mr Rush brought some accounts with claims of individuals to be decided— General Porter also— But I declined deciding henceforth any question involving a principle; considering myself as absolved from all responsibility, and referring every thing importing it to my Successor— I desired Mr Fendall to make out a Commission for Judge Hopkinson, and a pardon for J. B. Amedey—which he did and I signed them. Mr Gales the Mayor came, and I agreed to give my consent to the occupation by the Corporation, of a piece of Land beyond the Tiber, for a Basin, terminating the Canal— He will have the papers drawn, and I am to sign them— Mr Graham Commissioner of the Land-Office brought an answer to the Call of the Senate for the expences of the Office in 1827. but took it back to make an alternation which I suggested— J. B. Davis of Boston paid me a morning visit, and afterwards dined with us. Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith left us.
25. V:30 Wednesday. Rain.— Walk round the Square

Mr Silsbee introduced to me a Professor De Luce and a Mr Alphonso from the Island of Cuba— Coll Little a member of the House of Representatives, from Baltimore County, Maryland came and took leave of me— He expressed doubts whether he should be re-elected to the next Congress— I desired Mr Fendall to write to the Marshall of the Eastern District of Virginia to acknowledge the receipt of the pardon of John B. Amedey—he has been two years in prison under reprieve from a sentence of Death; and I have concluded, not to leave his fate uncertain beyond the term of this Administration— Mr Iredell of the Senate and Mr Maxwell of the House of Representatives, from the Committee of enrolled Bills brought me six Acts, which I signed. Mr Brent asked me to give him a testimonial of my Satisfaction with his conduct as Chief Clerk of the Department of State, which I very readily promised to give him. Mr Knight brought me an application for an appointment of his Son as a Cadet at West Point, together with several recommendations— I told him I would speak for him to the Secretary of War but I am apprehensive that he has made all of the Appointments for this year. Knight is at a loss what State to claim as his own; being a native of Vermont, long Resident in Louisiana, and having his family in Kentucky— Dr Todsen came to state his claim upon the Settlement of his Account—and thanked me for what I had done for him. I enclosed Judge Hopkinson’s Commission to him. I am endeavouring to extricate my self from all remnants of public business but they continue to crowd upon me— There was a Ball this Evening at Mr Vaughan’s which my Son John and his wife—Thomas B. and Abigail S. Adams attended— President Jackson’s Cabinet is arranged. Mr Van Buren, Secretary of State, S. D. Ingham Secretary of the Treasury, J. M’lean Postmaster General, John H. Eaton, Secretary of War, John Branch Secretary of the Navy; and John M. Berrien, Attorney General.
26. VI. Thursday— Walk round the Square—

Mr Fendall brought me a Commission to sign and Mr Brent the commercial Treaty with Brazil which arrived last Night— I sent for Mr Hay Chief Clerk of the Navy Department, who came and I requested him to send for the papers and plans belonging to the Department which were here— He told me of an accident which has befallen his father by the falling of plaster from the cieling upon him while in bed. Leslie was an insane person who said he had a Message to me from the Lord. That I am, had sent him to me— Sturgis and Bacon of Boston, and Relf of Philadelphia came on a visit together. Tilton applied for an appointment and brought a Letter of recommendation, too late. Judge Randall from Florida called to pay me a visit. The Reeder’s father and Son, were Quakers from Ohio— They were plain and blunt in their manners, but the father told me he liked men in civil life better than the Military— Coll. Abert came and took back to the topographical bureau at the War Department the Chronometer and Telescope of which I have had the use these three years. Captain Brooks called to ask the return of his Letters of recommendation. Dr Watkins came to urge the nomination of Cooper for an appointment of purser in the Navy— The Dr Mentioned that Coll. Towson had resigned his Office as Marshal for the inauguration; and was negotiating for a transfer of his Office as Paymaster-General, for that of Commandant of the Marine Corps— He is much scandalized at the ascendancy of Mrs Eaton; lately Mrs Timberlake— Dr Reynolds came to mourn the loss of the South Sea expedition in the Senate. Passet the Upholsterer came to ask a certificate which I could not give him— Mr Clay spoke of his own purposes as unsettled—whether he should come to Congress or not. He is to have several public dinners as he goes home, and to make speeches— I sent message N. 6. to Congress— Florida Canal— N. 12. to H.R.U.S. Capital Convictions; and N. 29. Nominations 30. Genl. Gaines’s inspection Reports. 31. Land-Office expenses 32 Brazilian Treaty.— Mrs Adams went to Meridian Hill.
27. VI. Friday. Walk round the Square

Mr Ringgold called twice this morning—first to enquire when the Inventory should be taken, of the furniture of this House, to be delivered over, which I told him could not be done, till after the third of March: all my Servants being till then constantly occupied with the removal of my own. The second time it was to say that General Jackson was desirous of receiving his visitors here after the Inauguration on the 4th. of March, if it would be perfectly convenient to me, but not otherwise— I desired him to tell the General that the house should be ready to receive him. Mr M’Culloh of Baltimore came to solicit an order to release the bondsmen of a man named Goodwin, prosecuted for Slave trading, and who has gone to the West-Indies but M’Culloh says will come back and take his trial— I told Mr M’Culloh that my official responsibility being about to terminate I had ceased to decide any questions of a doubtful nature; and must refer him to my Successor— Mr W. M’lean member of the House of Representatives from Ohio introduced Mr Reeves of that State; and took leave of me, as did Mr Dorsey member from Maryland, and Mr Miner from Pennsylvania, who wished me to decide upon a claim for Indian Agency—of Mr Woodbridge Secretary of Michigan Territory. But I referred it to my Successor. Judge Thompson introduced Coll Morgan of the Army and Mr Constant of New-York— Genl. Van Rensselaer, the Postmaster at Albany paid me a visit— Captain Bache came to obtain the alteration of a name in a list of army promotions— Lieutt. Graham instead of Turnbull as a Topographical Engineer, which was done— The Senate having adjourned yesterday just before my Son John reached the Capitol to deliver the Messages.— Fendall and Brent came concerning the Proclamations of the two ratified Indian Treaties. Charles Hay took back to the Navy Department, the plans of 5 Navy-Yards and of the Delaware Breakwater approved by me— Shaler, Ward and Simmons were visitors. Knight took back his papers and Marsh came for his. General Porter left with me a claim of Coll Towson’s, and young Southard a list of names for nomination as Pursers— Mr and Mrs Frye and Tom dined with us—
28. VI. Saturday.— Snow. Walk round the Square

Mr Hay came for Lists of the Navy Nominations which I have lately made, including 4 Pursers whom I nominated by Message N. 32 this day to S.U.S. I sent also Message N 7. to Congress with copies of the two Indian Treaties last ratified; and N. 13. to H.R.U.S. with documents relating to the late Customs Amendment Act of the British Parliament— Dr Swan, member from New-Jersey came for the Letters recommendatory of a Mr Miller for the Office of Collector at Amboy; which I gave him. Leslie the poor insane man came again with his Message from the Lord— Williams is the man whom I nominated for Superintendent of the road from Cumberland to Zanesville; but the Senate will not confirm him— Mr Nourse came, and after him Mr Briscoe who took my acknowledgment of the Deed from the Executors of W. N Boylston, of a Tomb—Dr Kirkland was here at the time and witnessed it— He is to embark with his wife the first of April from New-York for France, intending to spend two years in Europe— Mr Brent brought the Indian Treaties from the Department. Mr Hoffman had a long conversation with me advising me to attend the Inauguration next Wednesday and afterwards to visit the President, which I told him I would consider— Mr Jackson and Coll. Taylor were visitors. Coll. Bomford told me that he and Commodore Patterson had been deputed by the Subscribers to the Inauguration Ball to invite my attendance; but he had called upon me to enquire if it would be agreeable to me to receive such invitation— I told him that under present circumstances it would be as agreeable to me not to receive it, as I should be obliged to decline it if I did. Mr O’Brien, member of the House, left with me the papers of G. and J. Hobbs, of Eastport— Mr Reed of Massachusetts a petition of Winslow for discharge from prison. Mr Stone was a transient visitor— Coll. Dwight introduced Mr Rossiter, as one of his Constituents— Mr Hagner brought me the papers relating to a claim of D. Parker on Settlement of his Accounts as Adjutant General— I had advised that allowances should be made to him; such as had been made in parallel cases to others. Hagner shewed me that Swift’s was not a parallel loss— My Son’s wife and child and Abby S. Adams went out to Meridian Hill.
The Month.

Day— Much the same as last month. With the exception of two or three light Colds, my health has been better than for several preceding years. I have recovered much of my bodily strength, and only find the difficulty of writing increase upon me. This is a source of deep concern to me, as all the usefulness and all the promise of comfort before me, for my remnant of life will consist in the faculty of writing— But I must take the dispensations of Providence as they come— Thankful to heaven for the good Resigned and submissive to the severe. The month has been remarkable as the last of my public service, and the preceding pages will shew that the business of my office crowds upon me, with accumulation as it draws near to its end— Three days more and I shall be restored to private life and left to an old age of retirement, though certainly not of repose. I go into it with a combination of parties, and of public men, against my character and reputation such as I believe never before was exhibited against any man since this Union existed— Posterity will scarcely believe it—but so it is—that this combination against me has been formed, and is now exulting in triumph over me, for the devotion of my life, and of all the faculties of my Soul, to the Union—and to the Improvement, Physical, Moral and Intellectual of my Country. The North assails me for my fidelity to the Union—the South for my ardent aspirations of improvement— Yet bate I not a jot of heart and hope— Passion, Prejudice, Envy and Jealousy will pass— The Cause of Union and of Improvement will remain; and I have duties to it and to my Country yet to discharge— On the eleventh of this Month Andrew Jackson of Tennessee was declared to be elected President and John C. Calhoun Vice President of the United States for four years from the fourth of March next— On the same day, the President elect, arrived in this city and took lodgings at Gadsby’s Hotel. A self-constituted Central Committee, of persons pretending to be his exclusive friends and partizans, with John P. Van Ness at their head; undertook to usher him into the City: to order the firing of guns, and manifestations of public rejoicing in his honour, and to assume the Office of Masters of Ceremonies to introduce to him all his visitors. They continued to exercise these functions till the public disgust became audible
audible— They even published a regulation of the ceremony of his inauguration, and proclaimed Coll. Towson the Paymaster General, and one of their own number, Marshal for arranging the procession to the Capitol— This however has since been given up— The President-elect, a few days since sent for Coll. Towson, and requested him to resign his Office of Marshal for the central Committee, which he did, and the Marshal of the District of Columbia, is to have the ordering of the Commission as has been customary heretofore. Mrs Jackson having died in December, the General has signified his wish to avoid all displays of festivity or rejoicing, and all magnificent parade. He has not thought proper to hold any personal communication with me since his arrival. I sent him word by Marshal Ringgold, that I should remove with my family from the House so that he may if he thinks proper receive his visits of congratulation here on the 4th. of March. He desired Ringgold to thank me for this information— Spoke uncertainly whether he would come into the House on the 4th. or not; but said if it would be in any manner inconvenient to my family to remove he wished us not to hurry ourselves at-all, but to stay in the house as long as should suit our convenience, were it even a Month— He has with him his nephew Andrew Jackson Donelson with his wife, a Miss Easten, an adopted Son, named Jackson, and perhaps some others. His avoidance of me has been noticed in the newspapers. The Telegraph Newspaper has assigned for the reason of this incivility, that he knows I have been personally concerned in the publications against his wife, in the National Journal— This is not true—I have not been privy to any publication in any newspaper, against either himself or his wife— Within a few days another reason has been assigned— Mr David Hoffman of Baltimore, urged me to attend the inauguration, and said, in that event he was informed it was General Jackson’s intention to pay me a visit— His reason for not having done it before having been the chance there might have been of his meeting Mr Clay with me— Mr Ringgold says Mr M’lean the Postmaster General told him that he had conversed with the General, upon his abstaining from visiting me, and that the General had told him he came here
with the intention of calling upon me, but had been dissuaded from it by his friends— Mrs Adams went out to Meridian Hill on Thursday; and my Son’s wife and Abigail Adams this day. As I shall be constantly occupied with public business until and including the third of March I shall not be able to leave this House until the Evening of that day— The removal of my Effects and the preparation of the House for the reception of another family have so much absorbed the time that it has been, and will be impossible till after the third to take the inventory of the furniture belonging to the house, and to be delivered over— As the General had sent a courteous Message desiring us not to hurry our removal and had expressed himself very doubtful whether he should come in, I sent word to him By Mr Ringgold that it might take two or three days beyond the third before the inventory could be taken; he sent for answer that he wished not to put us to the slightest inconvenience, but that Mr Calhoun had suggested that there might be danger of the excessive crowds breaking down the rooms at Gadsby’s House, and the General had concluded if it would be perfectly convenient to us to receive his company at the President’s House after the Inauguration on Wednesday next— I have therefore concluded at all Events to leave the House on Tuesday— Michael Antony Giusta the man whom I engaged in my Service at Amsterdam in June 1814. and who has lived with me ever since, and his wife have both been engaged by the General to remain in the house and in the same capacity which they now hold— This Separation from Domestics who have so long lived in the family is among the painful incidents of the present time—
The following is the list of Domestics employed at the President’s House.

list.item: Giusta— Michael Antony. Steward and Butler.
Giusta— Mary (Newell) his wife. Assistant Housekeeper.
